name: Pimozide (Orap)
summary: Pimozide is a typical antipsychotic of the diphenylbutylpiperidine class, primarily used for managing Tourette's disorder and chronic psychotic disorders when other treatments are not effective or tolerated.
description: Pimozide is a long-acting dopamine receptor antagonist, particularly at D2 receptors, which reduces dopaminergic neurotransmission in the central nervous system. It is mainly indicated for suppressing motor and phonic tics in Tourette's disorder and may also be used for schizophrenia or delusional disorders. Due to potential cardiac risks, pimozide use requires careful ECG monitoring and dose adjustments.

contraindications: Concurrent use of CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., ketoconazole, clarithromycin)

items: Control of motor and phonic tics in Tourette's disorder when other medications fail or are not tolerated
Management of chronic psychotic disorders unresponsive to other antipsychotics

sections.text: Pimozide blocks postsynaptic dopamine D2 receptors in the brain, reducing excessive dopaminergic activity implicated in tics and psychotic symptoms.

adult.Tourette's disorder: Start at 1–2 mg/day orally, titrate slowly every other day; usual dose 2–10 mg/day in divided doses; max 10 mg/day.
adult.Psychosis: Individualized dosing; usually lower than for tics.

pediatric.Tourette's disorder (≥12 years): Start at 0.05 mg/kg at bedtime, increase every 3 days; usual dose 0.05–0.2 mg/kg/day; max 10 mg/day.

sections.geriatric: Lower initial doses and slower titration recommended.

sections.text: Onset: gradual over several days; Duration: long-acting, suitable for once-daily dosing.

sections.black_box: QT prolongation and risk of sudden death; contraindicated in patients with congenital long QT syndrome or history of cardiac arrhythmias.
other: Avoid use with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
Requires baseline and periodic ECG monitoring

items.risk: Increased pimozide levels and QT prolongation

sections.pregnancy: Category C; use only if benefits outweigh risks.
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in breast milk; caution advised.
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity to side effects; use lowest effective dose.

sections.text: Gradual dose reduction recommended to minimize withdrawal or rebound symptoms.

items: Particularly effective for severe tics resistant to first-line treatments like clonidine or risperidone.
Long half-life allows for once-daily dosing.
Cardiac monitoring is essential due to QT prolongation risk.

seo.title: Pimozide (Orap) - Antipsychotic for Tourette's Disorder
seo.description: Pimozide (Orap) is a dopamine antagonist used for severe Tourette's disorder and resistant psychotic conditions. Learn about uses, dosing, and cardiac safety.
